p: This method allowed us to detect the antibacterial activity of EOs in liquid media. MIC and MBC values of EOs were summarized in Tables 2 and 3. MIC values of general antibiotics are expressed in μg/mL in Table 4. Cinnamon bark, clove, citronella, and thyme presented the most potent inhibition against both Gram-negative and Gram-positive pathogens. The least sensitive strain to cinnamon and thyme was S. pyogenes (MIC: 0.41–0.43 mg/mL), while clove produced the lowest MIC value against this pathogen (MIC: 0.1 mg/mL). Among our tested materials thyme oil showed the most potent activity (MIC: 0.04 mg/mL) against S. mutans, which was followed by citronella, cinnamon bark, and clove. Citronella oil produced the lowest MIC value against S. pneumoniae. Peppermint presented inhibition against Streptococcus spp. in higher concentrations with MIC values in the range of 0.35–0.70 mg/mL.
